overview: In this subject, the student will develop skills in promotion of therapeutic relationships using dance and movement.  They will practice a range of clinical skills and methods to meet clients’ needs and promote self-expression through dance and movement. This will include fundamental techniques of kinaesthetic empathy, through attunement, mirroring and witnessing.

Students will practice adapting different dance forms and styles in order to engage members in a therapeutic context. Students will learn to manage the flow of a dance movement therapy session including a clear beginning, middle and end and smooth and timely transitions, and effectively manage group dynamics.
intended learning outcomes: draw from a range of clinical Dance Movement Therapy skills and methods to meet individual needs;
apply techniques such as witnessing, mirroring, kinetic empathy and attunement to advance the therapeutic relationship;
identify core facilitation skills necessary to work with individuals and groups.

assessments.description: Essay on one Dance Movement Therapy method studied to date and its therapeutic relevance. 1000 words
10-minute video demonstration of the techniques of kinaesthetic empathy, working in pairs in 'therapist-client' dyad; and a 1000-word written reflection. 2000 words (equivalent)

10-minute delivery of one Dance Movement Therapy activity demonstrating capacity to therapeutically adapt a chosen dance style to engage members of a Dance Movement Therapy group, and a 1000-word justification of choice and delivery of activities. 2000 words (equivalent)
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 80% of all scheduled classes.

Semester 2 (Early-Start).Contact hours: 36 hours, comprising one 2.5-hour fortnightly class and three 7-hour on-campus intensive days

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
